author: cautiousfox
title: Cross-Chain Ambassadors (v 1.0)
description: People are busy. Networking with other chains, understanding their needs and educating their communities about Catalyst/Cardano takes time.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer makes a simple, quick, but compelling case for offering bounties to bring projects from other chains over to Cardano. Catalyst has its own rules and learning curve that could be smoothed out by ambassadors. Since the proposer is intending to coordinate these efforts, we could probably do with a little more information about how the program will be managed, and how collaborative efforts will be handled. Will it be handled like sales team contractors? Can anyone bring in a bounty, or do they have to be vetted through the coordination process?
f6_assessments.q1: My concern with the project as proposed is with the team formation process. A finder's fee model would seem to lend itself better to open solicitation from community members who may happen to have connections to projects on other chains. If we're putting together teams of specific individuals, what will the "hiring" criteria be? And what's the ideal number of people to assign to the task given that there are only 10 slots, so to speak? The project notes the risk of hyper-competition, but what about maintaining morale for the "slower" headhunters. Does everyone give up after 10? Is it banked and carried over to the future in case funds are refreshed? How do you keep those people around? Volunteer enthusiasm can cover some of the gaps, but it shouldn't be counted upon.
f6_assessments.q2: With the sales contractor-like model being proposed here, it's worth considering why marketers are generally paid in closed sales and not points of contact, or for bringing someone to the floor for a demonstration. It's easy to game that system. Points of contact are great, but they're not easy to audit. Proposals submitted to Catalyst are great, but they don't tell us anything about the quality of who is submitting, or if the projects are legitimate. There's potential here, but there's still a little too much abstraction.
f6_assessments.reply: This was really good feedback. Thank you so much!

f6_assessments.q0: The difficulty in educating other chains' communities on Catalyst/Cardano is quite the hurdle to climb. Catalyst is channeling $400k into cross-chain collaborations on Fund 8 and if passed, Fund 9 will dedicate $900k into this effort. This may motivate protocols to send a proposal for expansion on to Cardano, only IF they know about it. In that sense, networking and outreach could aid in getting the word out. One of the metrics to measure in this Challenge is "Number of proposals including participants from other blockchain communities" and this proposal, if successful, would increase the number of proposals for Fund 9.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer, Tomi Astikainen, is one of the starters for this Fund 8 Challenge. We can see that this Challenge has already ushered in other protocols like KILT, a parachain on Kusama, to send their proposal to Catalyst. This information could be shared in the section on team members to display his effectiveness in delivery.

Moving on to the proposal itself, as the proposed solution to the lack of education problem is to "coordinate the efforts and incentivize the needed actions", I find it hard to see how the incentive structure effectively solves the problem. What if more than 10 proposals are submitted by other chains/protocols? How would the $1,000 be used for coordination efforts? As there are only 3 actions(coordination of efforts through Telegram group, encouraging and educating people to reach out, reporting on chains/communities contacted), is the $1,000 also a token of appreciation? Or is it meant for education material, strategic plans,etc? More elucidation on the budgeting aspects would help the proposal. The proposal also seems to lack an implementable plan on how best to approach a project or chain. If the proposer is looking to scale this Ambassador program, more details would be needed in the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal could benefit from quantifiable metrics. It seems like the proposer is projecting 10 proposals from other chains. Including this would be helpful. It is possible to track the progress of the program as it will be done on Telegram. This openness would be amazing for the community. An After Townhall event and a final report would also be helpful for Catalyst members, but could possibly be unnoticed by outsiders. As the problem looking to be solved is the lack of education, this could hinder the success of the program.
f6_assessments.reply: Great feedback. Thank you so much!

solution: $500 finder's fee to bring a proposer from a new chain/project can encourage Catalyst members to spend the needed time in networking.
experience: I was one of the three VCAs who started the Cross-Chain Collaboration challenge. I know how time-taking it is to do the needed networking and education to bring people in from outside of Catalyst.
